direction.raw_text: We have a sense of cyberspace-travel as we hurtle through a sky that's just beginning to get light.  There are a few stars but they fade and the sky turns a milky blue and a big computer sun starts to rise. We continue hurtling through space and see that we're heading over a computer version of the New York City skyline.  We move over Central Park.  It's fall and the leaves are glorious reds and yellows. We reach the West Side of Manhattan and move swiftly down Broadway with its stores and gyms and movies theatres and turn onto a street in the West 80s. Hold in front of a New York brownstone. At the bottom of the screen a small rectangle appears and the words:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the rectangle starts to fill with color, we see a percentage increase from 0% to 100%.  When it hits 100% the image pops and we are in real life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Early morning in New York. A couple of runners pass on their way to Riverside Drive Park. We go through the brownstone window into:

direction.raw_text: is asleep.  Kathleen, 30, is as pretty and fresh as a spring day.  Her bedroom cozy, has a queen-sized bed and a desk with a computer on it.  Bookshelves line every inch of wall space and overflow with books.  Framed on the children's classic.  Madeleine. As Kathleen wakes up, her boyfriend FRANK NAVASKY walks into the room.  He wears blue jeans and a workshirt.  He's carrying the New York Times.

NY152 Brinkley Kathleen hits the "delete" key and the first three letters -- all of them junk-mail -- are deleted and drop offscreen. Then she selects the "Read Mail" key for "NY 152 Brinkley". And the letter comes up: To: Shopgirl From: NY152 Re: Brinkley Kathleen starts to read the letter aloud:

direction.raw_text: A dog is sitting on a large green pillow on the floor. This is BRINKLEY.  The pillow has "Brinkley" embroidered on it. Brinkley's master, JOE FOX, a great-looking guy, full of charm and irony, comes into the kitchen and pours himself some orange juice.  He's half-dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but he chose to stay with me so that he could spend 18 hours a day sleeping on a large green pillow the size of an inner tube.  Don't you love New York in the fall?  It makes me want to buy school supplies.  I would send you a bouquet of newly-sharpened pencils if I knew your name and address.  On the other hand, this not knowing has its charms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling -- JOE Mmmmmhmmm -- Joe's girlfriend PATRICIA EDEN, in Armani head to toe, comes into the kitchen and turns on the $2000 espresso machine, which starts grinding beans.  She's carrying the morning papers.

direction.raw_text: I'm late. (indicating the newspaper) Random House fired Dick Atkins.  Good riddance.  Murray Chilton died.  Which makes one less person I'm not speaking to -- (she drains a cup of espresso as a second starts to come out of the machine) Vince got a great review.  He'll be insufferable.  Tonight,  PEN dinner -- JOE Am I going?

I pretend that we're the oldest and dearest friends -- as opposed to what we actually are, people who don't know each other's names and met in a Chat Room where we both claimed we'd never been before.

direction.raw_text: (V.O., CONTINUES) I hear nothing, not even a sound on the streets of New York, just the beat of my own heart.  I have mail.  From you.

direction.raw_text: As Kathleen comes onto Broadway at the corner of 83rd Street and starts downtown. Through a long lens we can see Joe, walking into blocks behind her. As Kathleen and Joe make their way down Broadway we see the West Side of Manhattan in the morning.  Mothers and fathers taking their kids to school, people on their way to work, dogs being walked.  School buses picking up kids, bakery trucks dropping off brown bags of bread in the doorframes of unopened restaurants. Kathleen stops at a newsstand, says good morning to the newsstand dealer, and picks up a New York Times. Metal grates are pulled up to open flower shops, nail salons, the pharmacy, fish store, the Cuban Chinese Restaurant, Zabar's. Joe stops at the same newsstand.  He buys all the papers -- the Times, Wall Street Journal, Post and Daily News.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & 73RD STREET - DAY - CONTINUOUS As Kathleen comes around the corner onto 73rd and stops in front of her store, a children's bookstore called "The Shop Around the Corner."  It is an irresistibly inviting store. There are twinkle lights in the windows, framing large stuffed animals reading children's books: Madeleine, Good Night Moon, Where the Wild Things Are.  A teddy bear in a pinafore is reading The Stupids Step Out.  Waiting for Kathleen in front is one of her employees, CHRISTINA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Christina.  It's a beautiful day. Isn't it the most beautiful day? Christina looks up at the sky as if seeing it for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess.  Yeah, sure. Kathleen unlocks the shop and cranks the grate, which rises, making a horrible noise.  Two cabs almost collide in front of the store, with a screech, and one cabdriver starts yelling obscenities at the other.  Kathleen unlocks the door to the store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you love New York in the fall? Christina looks at her puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kathleen turns the CLOSED sign on the door over to read

She looks around, and we see a small but charming children's bookstore, with wooden shelves, a tiny area where kids can sit and read, some charming posters and a glass case full of first editions of the Oz books and Alice In Wonderland, etc.  There's a playful display of witches, lit with twinkle lights covered with orange pumpkin globes and a sign reading "The Ten Best Witch List"  and a collection of witch books -- "The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe," "The Witches," "The Wizard of Oz." On the counter is a glass jar full of sugar-free lollipops. Kathleen hangs up her coat in the back of the store and suddenly stops to daydream.  A smile creeps onto her face. Christina looks at her.

direction.raw_text: And if you ever do meet her, you'll find out all the horrible details, and that will be that.  She'll turn out to have pictures of the Virgin Mary all over the walls.

direction.raw_text: I won't care. Kathleen sticks her head into the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can someone help me out here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George had a coup de foudre .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Christina's making fun of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't let her.  I believe in this, I completely believe in this.  It happened to Madame Bovary, at least six times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she was wrong every time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! (beat) Who was she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.  She was standing outside my building with the police and the reporters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What police and reporters?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no idea about that either. They found her on the roof.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dead body.  That's so sad.  But you fell in love.  That's so great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.  One other thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sign is now complete and it says: "Coming soon, just around the corner.  A Foxbooks Superstore." Kathleen and George and Christina stand there looking at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quel nightmare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It has nothing to do with us. It's big, impersonal, overstocked and full of ignorant salespeople.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But they discount.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But they don't provide any service.  We do. George and Christina nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kathleen is having lunch with Birdie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So really it's a good development.  You know how in the flower district, there are all these flower shops in a row so you can find whatever you want.  Well, this is going to be the book district. If you don't have it, we do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And vice versa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kathleen in the kitchen, unloading groceries.  Frank is standing there, plugging in an Olympia Report deluxe Electric typewriter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you are finished with Foxbooks, the Shop Around the Corner is going to be responsible for reversing the entire course of the Industrial Revolution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is so sweet, Frank.  Thank you. That is so sweet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey -- He holds his arms out.  They hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Although...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that doing there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to it.  Just listen-- He strikes a key.  Practically swoons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Olympia Report deluxe Electric Report.  As in gunshot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That sound is familiar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now listen to this. He puts his ear to the typewriter. Kathleen listens too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That whirring?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gentle and soothing lullaby of a piece of machinery so perfect -- KATHLEEN I know where I've heard it before.  I know. She whips a cover off the other typewriter on the table. It's the same machine exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I needed a backup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you have another one at your apartment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might, I might.  So what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're turning my apartment into a typewriter museum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll stop.  I'll try.  I probably can't. I see one and my knees go weak.  Anyway, what were you starting to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.  I was just wondering about my work and all.  I mean, what is it I do exactly?  All I really do is run a bookstore -- FRANK All you really do is this incredibly noble thing -- Kathleen nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I don't know if I -- FRANK (stopping her) Kathleen -- KATHLEEN But I just -- FRANK You are a lone reed. Kathleen looks puzzled. He sticks a piece of paper in the typewriter, starts typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a lone reed waving in the breeze standing strong and tall in the corrupt sands of commerce. He whips the piece of paper out of the typewriter and hands it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am a lone reed. (tries it on again) I am a lone reed. Clutching her piece of paper, she wanders into the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (over his shoulder, she notices the typewriter, breaks from the hug)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We hear the sound of a typewriter begin to clack away in the next room. Kathleen walks past her computer, looks at it.  Then she goes over to the window, looks out at her street at dusk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A group of schoolgirls in uniform, in two straight lines, walk past with a tall woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes over to the bookshelf and pulls out a copy of Madeleine by Ludwig Bemelmans and opens it to the illustration of the twelve little girls in two straight lines marching through the streets of Paris.  She looks at it, then looks up, lost in thought.  We hear the sound of the computer keys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes I wonder about my life.  I lead a small life.  Well, not small, but circumscribed.  And sometimes I wonder, do I do it because I like it, or because I haven't been brave?  So much of what I see reminds me of something I read in a book, when shouldn't it be the other way around? (continued) And hold on her as she thinks about this. In the other room, we hear Frank typing. Kathleen goes to the computer, turns it on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we see Kathleen, through her curtains, a small figure barely lit by her computer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't really want an answer.  I just want to send this cosmic question out into the void.  So goodnight, dear void.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drip is a cafe on Amsterdam Avenue with Fifties-style couches and chairs in cozy seating arrangements.  Kathleen is standing at the front counter with Christina, getting drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I went to the Foxbooks Website and you can buy anything.  They ship it to you in a day.  Maybe we should get a website.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother would never have wanted us to have a website.  "Every book you sell is a gift from your heart."  She always said that. As they walk toward the back of the cafe, Kathleen notices a stack of loose-leaf binders on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if they put us out of business?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's out of the question.  We're a fixture in the neighborhood.  We're practically a landmark. (indicating the binders) Men For Women, Women for Men, Women for Women -- what is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fill out one of these forms and they file it in the book and if someone wants to meet you, they arrange it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a stupid way to meet someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Compared to the Internet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My little thing on the Internet is just a lark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So it's still going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I do not plan to meet him. (indicating the book) Why do I get the feeling that you are in here somewhere? Christina flips the book open to her application.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came in here one night and drank too much coffee and filled one out. (off Kathleen's look) Well how am I supposed to meet someone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a runner.  Some day you will make eye contact with another runner and -- CHRISTINA No one ever even looks at me.  They don't.  On top of which, who are they? They could like the symphony.  I could never fall in love with someone who likes to go to the symphony -- KATHLEEN I know.  What are you supposed to do there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit.  You're supposed to sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could never fall in love with anyone who smokes cigars either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you what I hate.  Big fat legs like stumps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  I hate that too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The worst, the worst -- I could never, under any circumstances, love anybody who had a sailboat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither could I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I had to get up on Saturday morning knowing that I was about to go down to the pier and unravel all those ropes and put on all that sunblock -- CHRISTINA All that talk about the wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then you have to go out on the boat, and you sail and sail and sail until you are bored witless, and then, only then, do they say, let's turn around and you realize the trip is only half over, only it's not, because the wind has changed -- CHRISTINA It hasn't changed.  It's died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So then there's more talk about the wind. While you just float up and down trying not to get nauseous.  And when you finally get back, you have to clean up the boat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't people have boat maids?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.  There're all these people who wouldn't be caught dead polishing a doorknob in their house but put them on a boat and they want to rub down everything in sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe is on his sailboat.  He is polishing his brass and whistling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe -- Joe jumps off the boat onto the dock to greet his grandfather's daughter ANNABEL, 8, who is coming toward the dock with GILLIAN, his father's overdecorated 32-year-old fiance, her son, MATTHEW, 4, and the Nanny, MAUREEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello. (picks up Annabel) Annabel, how are you today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, big guy -- GILLIAN Don't I get a hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Gillian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kiss me.  I'm going to be your wicked stepmother. Joe gives her a peck on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nanny Maureen.  I brought her in case you couldn't handle the kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maureen's getting a divorce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to hear that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my own fault.  Never marry a man who lies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is so wise.  Remember that, Annabel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She taught Matt to spell his name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fox. F-O-X.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent, Matt. (to Maureen) Good work.  You can have the day off. I'll take over from here. (to Gillian) You must be late for something. Volunteer work at the Henry Street Settlement.  Packing bandages for Bosnian refugees.  A course in Chinese literature at Columbia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am.  I'm having my eggs harvested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a block street fair with little booths, sausage sandwich concessions, etc.  Annabel and Matt have been to the makeup booth.  Annabel is a cat and Matt is a pirate. Annabel is carrying a goldfish in a baggie as they walk toward Broadway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Joe, Annabel and Matt walk past.  There's some sort of toy miniature princess in a pointed hat sitting outside the store and a sign lit with twinkle lights: Storybook Lady today 3:30.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kathleen is sitting on a stool reading to a group of CHILDREN, including Annabel and Matt, who are crammed into her store. Joe is watching, along with some PARENTS as Kathleen reads from a Roald Dahl book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matt is sitting on the floor reading a book.  Kathleen is showing Annabel a copy of a book called Betsy-Tacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is her best friend Tacy, whose real name is Anastasia, and then in the next book Betsy and Tacy become friends with Tib, whose real name, I am sorry to tell you, is Thelma. In another section of the store: George is showing Joe a first edition of Swiss Family Robinson from the glass case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The illustrations are hand-tipped, which is why -- JOE It costs so much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's why it's worth so much. Joe smiles and turns to see Kathleen and Annabel at a whole shelf of Betsy-Tacy books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want all of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That might be an awful lot for your dad to buy at one time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dad gets me all the books I want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's very nice of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not my dad.  That's my nephew -- KATHLEEN Oh, I don't really think that's your nephew -- As Joe approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's true.  Annabel is my aunt.  Aren't you, Aunt Annabel? Annabel nods solemnly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Matt is -- KATHLEEN Let me guess. (to Matt) Are you his uncle?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His grandfather? Annabel and Matt start giggling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His great-grandfather?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm his brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annabel is my grandfather's daughter. And Matt is my father's son.  We are an American family. He smiles at Kathleen, who finds herself smiling back. Annabel suddenly sneezes. Kathleen takes a handkerchief from her sleeve.  It's an old fashioned hankie that's embroidered.  She offers it to Annabel, who instead wipes her nose with her hand and then looks at the handkerchief, a little puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A handkerchief.  Oh my, do children not even know what handkerchiefs are?  A handkerchief is a Kleenex you don't throw away.  My mother embroidered it for me -- you see?  My initials and a daisy, because daisies are my favorite flower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orchids are my favorite flower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what else children don't know? They don't know what a telephone booth is? Joe is looking at Kathleen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kathleen Kelly.  I own this store. Are you are?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe.  Just call me Joe. (quickly) We'll take these books. He gets the one Matt is reading.  And the two other Kathleen has gotten for Annabel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are wonderful books.  As Annabel gets older the characters in the books do, too. (to Annabel) You can grow up with Betsy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to come back again, aren't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is why we're never going to go under.  Our customers are loyal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're opening a Foxbooks around the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Foxbooks!  My Daddy -- JOE (gently putting his hand over her mouth)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: likes to buy at discount.  Don't tell anyone that, Annabel, it's nothing to be proud of -- MATT (spelling)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's amazing.  You can spell fox.  Can you spell dog?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Matt, look at this dinosaur book. Wouldn't you like a dinosaur book? Annabel, maybe you could read this to Matt while I wrap things up here. (moves them to a corner, to them quickly) Sit down, read, and don't listen to anything I say. Returns to counter and gives Kathleen some cash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the dinosaur book too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The world is not driven by discounts, believe me.  I've been in business forever.  I started helping my mother here after school when I was six years old.  I used to watch her, and it wasn't that she was selling books, it was that she was helping people become whoever they were going to turn out to be.  When you read a book as a child it becomes part of your identity in a way that no other reading in your life does. (stops herself) I guess I've gotten carried away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have, and you've made me feel... He can't finish the sentence.  He looks at her and sees, behind her on the shelf, a picture of a woman who is unmistakably Kathleen's mother, with a young Kathleen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enchanting, your mother was enchanting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was.  How did you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucky guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway.  She left the store to me, and I'm going to leave it to my daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How old is your daughter now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I'm not married.  But eventually. She smiles at Joe...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So Foxbooks can...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go to hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here you go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We ready? Annabel and Matt join him at the counter.  Kathleen gives them each a lollipop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bye, Kathleen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, Annabel.  Bye, Matt.  What about cat?  Can you spell cat?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someplace like the auditorium at the Museum of Broadcasting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe's girlfriend, who is the editor-in-chief of a New York publishing house called Eden Books, is standing at a podium at a sales conference.  In the audience are sales reps, wholesalers, etc.  There's a screen behind her with pictures of the authors being flashed on it as she speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now, the book you've all been waiting for, the book it's been my dreams to publish.  The legendary Veronica Grant has written her memoirs -- There's a burst of applause as a photograph of Veronica Grant flashes on screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and I'm happy to report it is just crammed with tragedy. (she laughs gaily) Just kidding, but seriously, it's all here: poverty, addiction, divorce, tracheotomies -- We see pictures of Veronica at eight with her sharecropper family, Veronica at 14 with her first child, Veronica with a series of husbands, Veronica in a wheelchair, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: her third husband beat her up, hip replacement, and an amazing face lift where all the injected fat fell to her chin. Now we see a blow-up of the book's jacket, with a picture of Veronica on it and the title: "Am I Rising from Ashes, or Did I Just Forget to Dust?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This book is fabulous.  And even if it weren't, it would sell like crazy, because Veronica is going to plug it to death on every talk show in America. This book... Patricia bursts into tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.  I can't talk about it without crying.  Veronica and I have so much in common -- well, not all the sad parts -- but we were both famous by the time we were 29 and, believe me, that's rough. (wipes her nose with a Kleenex, pulling herself together) Anyway, I just want to say that I'm especially thrilled to be publishing it. Veronica lives in my building and we met in the elevator.  By the time we had traveled from the eighth floor to the first, we had a deal.  First printing: one million copies. Everyone applauds enthusiastically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patricia is leaving, still surrounded by colleagues and sales reps congratulating her.  She is the soul of graciousness. Her assistant, Sarah, comes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a dentist appointment in twenty minutes.  So you should leave soon...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's my car number?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Car?  You didn't say anything about a car
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you an idiot?  Of course I need a car. God! She walks toward the exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patricia in the pouring rain, trying to hail a cab.  She spots one across the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taxi!  Taxi!  Taxi! She whistles -- a longshoreman's whistle. The cab makes a U-turn, but instead of stopping for Patricia it stops about twenty feet ahead for a MAN in an overcoat who gets into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me -- what are you doing?  This is my taxicab. (to the driver) Don't take him.  I am telling you right now, and I am memorizing your number, don't take him. (to the man) Who the fuck do you think you are?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you going uptown?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in.  I'll drop you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the cab turns onto Eighth Avenue, starts uptown. Patricia is dialing her cell phone.  She's elaborately ignoring the man who stole her cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Veronica, it's Patricia, you should have been there, it was unbelievable, we're going to sell truckloads of your book. Call me. She hangs up, folds up the phone, puts it back in her purse as the cab moves on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you an editor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am a rabbi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my God, I said fuck to a rabbi.  I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you don't mind my asking, but are you Jewish?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should come to our temple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not really religious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I am surprised, you seem like a very religious person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're kidding, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are at West End Avenue and 83rd Street.  Every Friday night, we have a joyous time, everyone dancing, everyone singing.  Also some wisdom.  Perhaps you have heard of us, we are known as The Singles Temple. He smiles at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a very good place to calm down. The cab stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, look, I am already here.  Very nice to meet you. (gives the cabbie money) Take this woman to her destination. He gets out.  Closes the door.  A beat too late:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank comes up the stoop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kathleen is dressed up for a party. Frank walks in, looks meaningfully at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw him.  I actually saw him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe it.  I saw William Spungeon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought he was in Mexico.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe he's in Mexico, but today he was in New York.  The most brilliant and reclusive novelist in the history of the world is here, in this neighborhood.  He may be living on this very block.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you see him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was on the subway -- INT. SUBWAY - DAY FRANK (V.O.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and this musician got onto the train -- Frank is sitting on the subway, reading the Village Voice. The door between the cars opens and a man playing the clarinet enters the car. No one looks up except Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and I suddenly saw him, sitting directly across from me doing the crossword puzzle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you know it was him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looked exactly the same as his high school yearbook picture, which happens to be the last photograph ever taken of him. Frank takes out his billfold on the subway, pulls out a piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP - FOLDED PIECE OF PAPER As Frank unfolds a newspaper clipping of a yearbook picture of William Spungeon at 17. Frank compares the photo of Spungeon with the person sitting across the way.  They don't look remotely alike except that the boy in the picture and the man on the subway are both wearing the same style glasses. The subway stops at 79th Street, and William Spungeon gets off. Frank follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Frank comes out of the subway station and looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I followed him. Frank sees Spungeon cross 79th.  He follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: &H BAGELS - CONTINUOUS Frank follows Spungeon, who hurries into H&H Bagels passing a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: holding a paper cup at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He went into H&H and bought a bagel with everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: &H BAGELS - A MINUTE LATER As Spungeon leaves the store, passing the paper cup, which we now realize that Frank, in dark glasses, is holding. Spungeon drops his newspaper in a garbage container.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He dropped his crossword into the garbage and I rescued it. Frank plucks the puzzle from the trashcan, follows Spungeon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spungeon at the counter in the shoe store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he went into a sporting good store and bought tube socks, 6 pair for $7.99. We see Frank, peeking out at him from behind a stack of running pants.  Suddenly he's distracted by a couple of joggers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William Spungeon and tube socks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.  I don't want to dwell on it. Frank looks back at the counter.  Spungeon's gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then I lost him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank waves the crossword puzzle in front of Kathleen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know what this is worth? He takes an empty instant-frame from the closet, puts the puzzle into it and sets it next to the typewriters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six months ago, when you and I first met, I knew everything about myself -- what I would be doing for the rest of my life and even the person I would be doing it with.  Now I know nothing. On the door is a small sign.  "After 42 years, we are closing our doors.  We have loved being part of your lives." Kathleen turns out the light in the store and opens the door. The little bell over the door jingles. Kathleen reaches up on her tiptoes for the bell and detaches it. Then she comes out of the store, carrying the bell. Kathleen locks the door and reaches down to operate the grate for the last time. The grate starts to lower. Kathleen looks at her store, one last time.  Then she walks off, carrying the bell.  We hear it jingle in the night. And hold on The Shop Around the Corner, and it slowly turns into a computer-enhanced version of itself. And then, suddenly, it vanishes with a poof, leaving an empty screen.

direction.raw_text: Who fights about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some people.  Not us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We would never. A long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If only...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please.  I have to go. She doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me ask you something?  How come you'll forgive him for standing you up and you won't forgive me for a little tiny thing like putting you out of business? Kathleen looks at him.  Shakes her head. They look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh how I wish you would. It's all Kathleen can do not to forgive him. It's all Joe can do not to kiss her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really do have to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't want to be late. She's in agony. He turns and walks away. After a moment, she does too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we see Kathleen come down the street and walk into her house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she comes out of the apartment house, having changed her clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she comes toward the entrance to the park.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Kathleen comes down a path in the park, near 88th Street. She comes to a stop. Looks around. A young woman in running clothes passes by. A young father pushing a baby in one of those strollers runners use to push babies in. Kathleen looks at her watch. Suddenly she hears a noise.  A dog barking. And Brinkley comes around the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brinkley!  Brinkley! And hold on Kathleen as she sees.
direction.name: direction
